decisions.title: Your First Big Payout
decisions.scenario: You‚Äôve been doing DoorDash around Albany/Troy and babysitting on weekends. This month was amazing: graduation parties, summer orders, and extra babysitting. Your bank app shows a total of about $1,200 coming in this month (after DoorDash fees, before taxes). You currently have $100.
decisions.context_info: Gig income feels like a paycheck, but it isn‚Äôt. No taxes are withheld automatically, and your car (gas, oil, tires) is your income tool. A smart first move is separating money you can spend from money you‚Äôll owe later.

choices.label: üéâ Treat yourself and spend most of it

immediate_outcome.text: You celebrate hard: new outfits, eating out, and a night out downtown. It feels worth it after grinding. You don‚Äôt track anything‚Äîjust vibes.

delayed_consequence.text: Orders slow down and gas prices jump. Your phone bill hits, then an unexpected car expense. Your account dips negative and you get hit with fees. You start declining deliveries because it‚Äôs not even worth the gas.
delayed_consequence.why: With gig work, income can drop fast. Without a buffer, one surprise expense turns into overdraft fees and missed payments‚Äîespecially when your car costs rise.

immediate_outcome.text: You set up three buckets: spending, savings, and a ‚Äòtax envelope.‚Äô You still enjoy your money, but you don‚Äôt lose control of it.

delayed_consequence.text: When deliveries slow down, you‚Äôre annoyed‚Äîbut not panicked. You cover your bills, keep working, and you don‚Äôt need to borrow money. You‚Äôre able to take a better opportunity when it shows up (like more reliable babysitting hours).
delayed_consequence.why: Buffers are power. For gig workers, savings and a tax envelope reduce stress and prevent small problems from becoming expensive emergencies.

choices.label: ü§ù Track every delivery + ask a mentor how to do gig money

immediate_outcome.text: You start logging miles, gas, and earnings. A mentor tells you the cheat code: track deductions and plan for taxes early. It‚Äôs not flashy, but you feel in control.

delayed_consequence.text: Because you tracked mileage and expenses, you realize which areas and times actually pay. You cut low-profit deliveries and keep more money without working more hours.
delayed_consequence.why: Gig work is a business. Tracking expenses helps you see your true hourly rate and avoid ‚Äòworking for free.‚Äô

decisions.title: Tax Season Surprise
decisions.scenario: It‚Äôs tax season. You get your 1099 forms and realize you owe about $850 in self-employment taxes. Nobody warned you. You have bills due this month and you‚Äôre stressed.
decisions.context_info: Gig income usually has no withholding. Self-employment taxes can surprise people because you‚Äôre responsible for both income tax and payroll taxes. The earlier you plan, the less painful it is.

choices.label: üò¨ Ignore it for now and deal with it later

immediate_outcome.text: You avoid it. You tell yourself you‚Äôll handle it later. It feels good for a moment because you keep your cash right now.

delayed_consequence.text: You get a scary notice and late penalties add up. Now you owe more than before and you have to scramble. You take extra deliveries, burn out, and still feel behind.
delayed_consequence.why: Ignoring taxes can trigger penalties and interest. For inconsistent income, that turns into stress and forces you to grind harder just to catch up.

choices.label: üí≥ Pay it with a credit card to stop the stress

immediate_outcome.text: You pay it off with a credit card. The relief is immediate: no scary notices. But now you‚Äôre carrying a balance.

delayed_consequence.text: Interest starts piling up. You miss one payment during a slow month and your score drops. You feel trapped because you‚Äôre working to pay interest instead of building savings.
delayed_consequence.why: Credit cards can help in emergencies, but high interest makes problems bigger if you don‚Äôt have a payoff plan‚Äîespecially with variable income.

choices.label: üìÑ Learn gig taxes + set up a plan (even if it‚Äôs smaller payments)

immediate_outcome.text: You learn the basics: deductions, mileage, and setting aside money per week. You create a plan and stop guessing. It‚Äôs not fun, but it‚Äôs empowering.

delayed_consequence.text: You file correctly and reduce what you owe by tracking deductions. You don‚Äôt love paying taxes, but it‚Äôs controlled‚Äîno panic. You start thinking bigger about stable income options.
delayed_consequence.why: Understanding deductions and planning weekly reduces the ‚Äòtax shock‚Äô that traps a lot of young gig workers.

decisions.title: Car = Your Income
decisions.scenario: Your car starts making a terrible noise. A mechanic quotes $600 for repairs. Without your car, your DoorDash income drops to almost zero. You need a decision today.
decisions.context_info: For gig workers, car costs aren‚Äôt optional. Repairs, maintenance, and insurance are part of your ‚Äòbusiness.‚Äô The best outcomes usually come from avoiding panic decisions (like high-interest debt) and building an emergency fund specifically for car costs.

choices.label: üõ†Ô∏è Pay cash from savings and fix it immediately

immediate_outcome.text: You pay from savings. It hurts to watch the money go, but you‚Äôre back on the road and earning again within a day.

delayed_consequence.text: Because you solved it fast, you keep your income steady. But you learned a hard lesson: you need a dedicated car emergency fund so one repair doesn‚Äôt wipe you out.
delayed_consequence.why: Savings prevents you from paying interest, but you still need to rebuild buffers so your next surprise doesn‚Äôt become a crisis.

choices.label: üí≥ Put the repair on a credit card and keep driving

immediate_outcome.text: You put it on a credit card. You‚Äôre relieved because you can keep working, but now you‚Äôve added a big monthly payment to your life.

delayed_consequence.text: During a slow month, you can‚Äôt pay the full balance. Interest hits and your score takes a small hit. You start feeling like you‚Äôre running in place.
delayed_consequence.why: Debt can keep you afloat short-term, but variable income makes consistent repayment harder‚Äîinterest punishes inconsistency.

choices.label: üîç Get a second quote + cut low-profit deliveries going forward

immediate_outcome.text: You shop around and find a lower quote. You also decide to stop taking deliveries that don‚Äôt meet your minimum profit after gas. You treat this like a business now.

delayed_consequence.text: You earn slightly less per day but keep more per hour. You rebuild savings steadily and feel less stressed because you‚Äôre not burning out for tiny profits.
delayed_consequence.why: The goal isn‚Äôt just working more‚Äîit‚Äôs keeping more. Profit rules + expense tracking protects gig workers from ‚Äòinvisible losses.‚Äô
